Award.AwardTitle: Exploring Carrier Spin Injection, Transport, and Trapping in Diamond
Award.AbstractNarration:
Methods to control interactions between individual atoms in solid state crystals are important for next generation technologies that will encode information in atomic spins. This project will pioneer a new approach for manipulating one atom's spin conditionally on the quantum mechanical spin of another. Individual atoms such as point defects in a diamond crystal lattice where a nitrogen atom is substituted for a carbon atom, known as NV centers, will be used. Individual NV centers will be controlled with optical and electronic pulses so they can send spin-dependent signals to each other. NV centers in diamond are already known to be valuable resources for storing and processing quantum information locally. But there are still fundamental questions about how to build a network that can shuttle quantum information back and forth between several NV centers. This project addresses that challenge by using laser light and electric fields to create a spin-dependent motion of an electric charge from one NV center to another NV center. The understanding to be gained from this effort will help with the effort to build components for new and more powerful types of computers called quantum computers. Furthermore, the approach used here will pioneer quantum computer components that use solid state devices operating at room temperature to process quantum information. Besides the technological and scientific advantages, the proposed research is expected to have a broad educational outcome because it offers students a unique inter-disciplinary scientific education and the ability to interact with a wide network of collaborating labs. These activities gain special meaning at City College, a minority serving institution with a uniquely diverse population of inner-city students.

This research program explores the use of photo-generated charge carriers as a bus to communicate between separate, non-interacting NVs within a diamond crystal or nano-structure. Diamond is arguably an ideal platform for quantum spintronics because it has inversion symmetry, contains a low concentration of spin-active nuclei, and features one of the weakest spin-orbit couplings. However, virtually no investigation of the carrier spin dynamics in diamond has yet been carried out, because injection and detection of spin polarized carriers through known strategies (e.g., optical excitation or ferromagnetic interfaces) has proven difficult. This project circumvents prior complications via a flexible scheme where NV centers alternatively serve as a source or a probe of carrier spin polarization. Building on prior observations the initial goal is to gain a fuller understanding of the physics governing the dynamics of charge carriers, including photo-ionization, diffusion, and carrier trapping. With focus on the NV center and substitutional nitrogen centers, the research plan encompasses a broad set of experiments designed to explore deterministic injection, transport, and capture of spin-polarized carriers. Special attention will be devoted to the problem of coherent spin transport, particularly in its ability to generate entanglement between qubits not interacting directly. While the emphasis is on the phenomenology and physics, the research plan also calls for various proof-of-concept devices conceived to gain adequate control of the dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quantum algorithms running exponentially faster than their classical counterparts combined with quantum error-correction protocols promise to revolutionize the way we process information. Despite accelerated progress, however, practical implementations are proving extraordinarily challenging due to competing needs, namely, processing units must remain robust against environmental noise without hampering our ability to control and monitor their temporal evolution. Among multiple rivaling physical platforms, color centers in wide-bandgap materials such as diamond have emerged as an attractive alternative: Typically formed by vacancies, and/or atomic impurities, these 'spin-qubits' absorb and emit light in a region of the spectrum where the crystal itself is transparent, and hence can be detected individually with the aid of optical microscopy techniques.

Although producing scalable quantum devices with multiple interacting spin qubits remains challenging, one alternative approach relies on the use of charge carriers as a bus. Building on this notion, work during this grant centered on gaining a fuller understanding of the physics governing the dynamics of photo-generated charge carriers in diamond, including defect ionization, diffusion, and carrier trapping. We focused on the nitrogen-vacancy (NV) and silicon-vacancy (SiV) centers in diamond but we also explored emitters in hexagonal boron nitride, an emergent 2D material featuring color centers with attractive emission properties. We list below some of the research highlights.  

  • We implemented a suite of multi-color confocal microscopy techniques to show that in the presence of photo-generated electrons and holes, SiV (NV) centers behave very differently, selectively transforming into the negative (neutral) charge state. We also demonstrated that, unlike NVs, SiVs ionize via single photon processes and gathered information on the energy structure of this defect, particularly on the relative position of the ground state within the diamond bandgap. Building on this work, we demonstrated on-demand SiV and NV charge initialization over large areas and showed these defects can be exploited as local memories for optical storage of classical information.
  • We investigated spin-to-charge conversion, i.e., the set of strategies allowing one to produce a given NV charge state depending on the original electron spin state. Since the NV charge state can be monitored almost non-destructively, such strategies are important in their ability to improve the readout sensitivity in spin-based sensing protocols. Working with ensembles, we demonstrated tenfold sensing measurement speedup for millisecond long magnetic resonance sequences. Subsequently, we used ancilla traps in the qubit vicinity to capture and store the carriers generated upon spin conditional ionization, and showed this approach to spin qubit detection can potentially reach up to ten-fold enhanced sensitivity compared to existing methods.
  • Working with Australian collaborators, we theoretically showed that transfer of carriers between separate spin qubits can take place without physical transport, via a virtual quantum state created by two coherent laser beams, a process akin to teleportation. In particular, our models showed that, for two NV centers in a diamond nanowire, high-fidelity carrier transfer can be achieved over distances of order hundreds of nanometers in timescales of order hundreds of nanoseconds.
  • With collaborators in Japan, we made use of room- temperature magnetic surface spin waves (MSSW) to mediate the interaction between the microwave field from an antenna and the spin of an NV center in diamond. We showed that this transport spans distances exceeding 3 mm, a manifestation of the MSSW robustness and long diffusion length. Using the NV spin as a local sensor, we found that the MSSW amplitude grows linearly with the applied microwave power, suggesting this approach could be extended to amplify the signal from neighboring spin qubits several-fold.
  • Since the behavior of point defects is, in general, sensitive to the crystalline environment, we studied the dynamics of charge conversion of NVs engineered to lie near the diamond surface. We found that the ionization and recombination rates of shallow NVs increase dramatically with the density of ion implantation compared to those in bulk diamond. Further, we found that these rates grow linearly, not quadratically, with laser intensity, indicative of single-photon processes enabled by NV state mixing with other defect states. These observations suggest that the NV ionization properties can be actively controlled via engineered surface states.
  • In collaboration with the Menon group at CCNY we extended our prior work on the dynamics of point defects in hexagonal boron nitride (hBN). Working with nm-thick hBN layers, we demonstrated deterministic activation of single defects; further, we found that the defect emission - typically exhibiting large spectral shifts, depending on the particular emitter - is preferentially clustered around a much narrower region of the spectrum.

Overall, the work connected to this project led to twelve scientific articles, ten of which were published in high impact journals. It also served to train two graduate students and several undergraduates. Four postdocs contributed at different stages; two of them continue working with the PI while the other two have moved on to positions in academia.
